intro: Ferula subvelutina, commonly known as the velvet ferula, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its tall, slender stems and large, lance-shaped leaves that are covered in a fine, velvety down. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers arranged in a terminal umbel, which bloom in the summer months. Its roots are thick and fleshy, often used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory properties. Ferula subvelutina is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing resilience to drought and extreme temperatures.
